channel.title: Network analysis on CSE Thesis Musings
channel.description: Recent content in Network analysis on CSE Thesis Musings

item.title: Packet Analysis
item.description: Target IP: 10.10.10.8 MAC: 64:90:c1:1d:24:c4 MAC OUI (64:90:C1) - Beijing Xiaomi Mobile Software Co, Ltd Filtering the data We have a ‘lot’ of network traffic that isn’t related to the operation of the device - such as STP, SSDP, DHCP, ARP and other traffic that occurs - even without the presence of the device, so let’s remove these.

item.title: 26/10/2021 Progress Update
item.description: Have been preoccupied with getting a bunch of stuff repaired/quoted/replaced after a power surge hit “some” (a lot) devices. Anyhow, I was out of network cables so I went ahead and crimped some more. The Roborock IoT DHCP and WAN comes out from the router (top, eth8) into the TP-Link switch (bottom right, eth5) The port mirror sink is on the switch (eth2) The wireless access point is on the switch (eth1)

item.title: Capturing Packets on Android
item.description: In order to capture the network activity during the process of pairing the Roborock - I needed to also log the network activity from my Android phone that was running Xiaomi Home. I ended up using PCAPdroid, which allowed me to target a specific app (or just everything) to capture network activity from.

item.title: 25/10/2021 Progress Update
item.description: Observations Idle Power draw during idle: 0.2W Whilst Charging Wattage Current Internal AP Xiaomi procedure Hosts an AP on boot (or is it just pairing?

item.title: Capturing Network Activity (Securely)
item.description: In order to better understand what the vacuum cleaner is doing, I need to figure out what the vacuum cleaner is both sending and receiving! This means that I will need to do some packet capturing, to get the TCP / UDP / etc… packets; but what’s the best (and budget-friendly) way to do that?
